Josh,

I'm not totally familiar with Matlab assignment protocol, but it
looks like, rather than passing a copy of the gas1 object to the
definition of gas2, matlab is instead passing a pointer to the gas1
object.  Thus, when the gas1 object is changed, and then gas2 is
called, gas2 seeks out the address where gas1 is stored, where of
course it finds the new, updated gas1.

Instead, I'd recommend initializing each object separately:
gas1 = IdealGasMix('gri30.xml');
gas2 = IdealGasMix('gri30.xml');

Hope this helps,
Steven




--- Josh Freeh <jef15@...> wrote:

> 
> Hi everyone -
> 
> I am trying to track two gases (of type Solution) in a Matlab file.
> When I modify one of the gases, the other changes as well. I'm
> not sure if it's something with Matlab's variable handling or
> something with the Cantera code itself. I plan on trying to
> duplicate this in either Python or C++  to investigate whether it
> is something in Cantera. In the meantime, here's a short Matlab
> script that demonstrates this issue:
> 
> clear all;
> gas1 = IdealGasMix('gri30.xml');
> gas2 = gas1;
> gas1
> set(gas2,'T',500);
> gas1
> gas2
> 
> gas1 should still be at 300K but it is showing up at 500K like
> gas2.
> 
> Any thoughts?
> 
> Thanks in advance -
> 
> Josh Freeh
> 
> 
> 
>
